overview: A 36-week Common Core 6th grade math course covering the full 6.NS / 6.RP / 6.EE / 6.G / 6.SP standards. Starts with a diagnostic boot camp to repair 5th-grade gaps, then builds through number system fluency, ratios and rates, expressions and equations, geometry, statistics, integers, and ends with an applied number sense bridge to pre-algebra. Every skill is spiraled all year so nothing vanishes.
naturalProgression: Repair decimal, fraction, and integer foundations from 5th grade
Master multi-digit and decimal division plus all fraction operations
Build ratio language, unit rate reasoning, and equivalent ratio fluency
Write, evaluate, and simplify algebraic expressions using properties
Solve one-step and two-step equations and inequalities from context
Calculate area, surface area, and volume of 2D and 3D figures
Describe and compare data distributions using center and variability
Extend the number line to integers, graph in all four quadrants
Apply percent intro, mixed problem solving, and bridge to 7th-grade algebra

domains.6.NS: The Number System — fluency with multi-digit/decimal operations, fraction operations, integers, coordinate plane
domains.6.RP: Ratios and Proportional Relationships — ratio concepts, unit rates, equivalent ratios, percent
domains.6.EE: Expressions and Equations — algebraic expressions, properties of operations, equations, inequalities
domains.6.G: Geometry — area, surface area, volume of polygons and prisms
domains.6.SP: Statistics and Probability — statistical questions, distributions, measures of center and variability

aiInstructionModel.approach: AI-led gradual release with concrete-to-abstract progression
aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads instruction using the gradual release model, designed for 11-12 year olds transitioning from arithmetic to pre-algebra. Every concept starts with a concrete context (money, measurement, sports, cooking), moves to pictorial representations (number lines, area models, bar diagrams), then formalizes to abstract notation. The AI prioritizes fluency-building through spaced practice and catches misconceptions before they cascade.

phases.aiRole: Introduce the concept with a concrete, relatable context. Activate prior knowledge. Define vocabulary in plain language and connect to what students already know.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the scenario, recall prior skills, identify key vocabulary

phases.aiRole: Walk through 2-3 worked examples showing every step. Use visual models (number lines, area diagrams, tables) alongside symbolic work. Narrate the thinking, not just the doing.
phases.studentRole: Follow along, note each step, identify the pattern, ask clarifying questions

phases.aiRole: Present scaffolded problems. Ask guiding questions. Let the student attempt each step before confirming. Catch errors immediately and redirect with a question, not a correction.
phases.studentRole: Attempt each problem step-by-step, explain reasoning, accept feedback

phases.aiRole: Assign independent problems mixing computation with application. Include at least one word problem. Require students to show work and check answers.
phases.studentRole: Solve independently, show all work, verify answers, explain approach

phases.aiRole: Short formative check: 3-5 problems targeting the skill. Assess fluency (speed + accuracy). Flag for reteach or advance.
phases.studentRole: Complete the check independently, demonstrate fluency

aiDecisionRights: Adjust problem difficulty based on observed fluency — skip ahead if strong, drop back if shaky
Choose contexts appropriate for 11-12 year olds (money, sports, cooking, gaming, school scenarios)
Spiral in prior skills when relevant (fraction fluency in ratio work, integer rules in coordinate plane)
Use visual models (area models, bar diagrams, number lines) until students demonstrate they don't need them
Flag foundational gaps (multiplication facts, fraction basics) and address before proceeding

modules.title: Start-of-Year Boot Camp
modules.preview: Place value, decimals, fraction review, integer basics, multiplication/division fluency, and expression writing
essentialQuestions: Which 5th-grade gaps will wreck my 6th-grade year if I don't fix them now?
Can I add fractions, divide decimals, and write simple expressions without hesitation?

modules.title: Checkpoint: Boot Camp Diagnostic
modules.preview: Diagnostic assessment to identify 5th-grade gaps in decimals, fractions, integers, and basic expressions

modules.title: Number System and Fluency
modules.preview: Multi-digit division, decimal division, fraction operations, GCF/LCM, and absolute value
essentialQuestions: Why does dividing by a fraction mean multiplying by the reciprocal?
When do I actually need the GCF or LCM in real life?

modules.title: Checkpoint: Quarter 1 — Number System and Ratios
modules.preview: Assessment covering fraction/decimal division, GCF/LCM, ratio language, unit rates, and equivalent ratios

modules.title: Ratios and Rates
modules.preview: Ratio language, unit rates, equivalent ratios, ratio/rate problem solving, and measurement conversions
essentialQuestions: How do I know which quantity should be the 'per 1' in a unit rate?
When I double a recipe, am I using ratios even if I don't call them that?

modules.title: Expressions and Variables
modules.preview: Writing and evaluating expressions, combining like terms, distributive property, and parts of expressions
essentialQuestions: Why do mathematicians use letters instead of just leaving blanks?
How does the distributive property make hard multiplication easier?

modules.title: Checkpoint: Quarter 2 — Expressions and Equations
modules.preview: Assessment covering algebraic expressions, properties, equations, and inequalities

modules.title: Equations and Inequalities
modules.preview: Solve one-step and two-step equations, intro to variables on both sides, inequalities, and word problems
essentialQuestions: What does it mean to 'solve' an equation — and how do I check?
How is solving an inequality different from solving an equation?

modules.title: Geometry: Area, Surface Area, Volume
modules.preview: Area of triangles and parallelograms, composite figures, nets, surface area, and volume of prisms
essentialQuestions: Why is the area of a triangle exactly half the area of the rectangle it came from?
What real-world problem requires me to know the surface area vs the volume?

modules.title: Checkpoint: Quarter 3 — Geometry and Statistics
modules.preview: Assessment covering area, surface area, volume, data displays, and measures of center and variability

modules.title: Statistics: Distributions and Summary Measures

essentialQuestions: What makes a question 'statistical' vs just a regular question?

essentialQuestions: Why does -5 feel colder than -2 even though 5 is bigger than 2?
How do the four quadrants help us organize information about the real world?

modules.title: Checkpoint: Quarter 4 — Integers, Applied Skills, and Cumulative
modules.preview: Assessment covering integers, coordinate plane, percent, mixed problem solving, and cumulative review

modules.title: Applied Number Sense + Algebra Bridge
modules.preview: Mixed problem solving with ratios, fractions, and equations; percent intro; unit conversions; multi-step real-world tasks
essentialQuestions: How do ratios, fractions, and percent all connect to each other?
Am I ready for 7th-grade math — can I solve a multi-step problem start to finish?

modules.title: End-of-Year Spiral + Mastery Review
modules.preview: Mixed review across 6.NS, 6.RP, 6.EE, 6.G, 6.SP — targeted reteach and cumulative assessment

spiralStrategy.dailyWarmup: 2 review problems (fraction/decimal/integer fluency) + 1 current-skill problem, 5-7 minutes
spiralStrategy.weeklyQuiz: 10-15 min quiz, mostly prior skills — fraction division, unit rates, simple equations
spiralStrategy.monthlyMixedCheck: Fraction division + unit rates + simple equations mixed assessment
nonNegotiableThreads: Interpreting data displays and describing distributions

aiGuidanceNotes: This is the year where students transition from arithmetic to pre-algebra. Every gap from 5th grade will cascade. The boot camp exists to catch those gaps. Fraction fluency is the #1 predictor of 6th-grade success — if a student can't add fractions or divide decimals fluently, every subsequent unit will struggle. Use real-world contexts constantly (money, cooking, sports, gaming) to make abstract concepts stick for 11-12 year olds. When teaching expressions and equations, emphasize the REASONING behind inverse operations, not just procedural steps.
